translations.Gutenberg:
Es ist schwer, verstanden zu werden: besonders wenn man gangasrotogati
denkt und lebt, unter lauter Menschen, welche anders denken und leben,
nämhch kurmagati oder besten Falles "nach der Gangart des Frosches"
mandeikagati - ich thue eben Alles, um selbst schwer verstanden zu
werden? - und man soll schon für den guten Willen zu einiger Feinheit
der Interpretation von Herzen erkennthch sein. Was aber "die guten
Freunde" anbetrifft, welche immer zu bequem sind und gerade als
Freunde ein Recht auf Bequemhchkeit zu haben glauben: so thut
man gut, ihnen von vomherein einen Spielraum und Tummelplatz des
Missverständnisses zuzugestehn: - so hat man noch, zu lachen; - oder
sie ganz abzuschaffen, diese guten Freunde, - und auch zu lachen!

translations.Hollingdale:
It is hard to be understood: especially when one thinks and lives gangasrotogati 
among men who think and live otherwise, namely kurmagati or at best ‘as the frog 
goes’, mandeikagati — I am certainly doing everything I can to be hard to understand 
myself! — and one ought to be heartily grateful even for the will to some subtlety in 
interpretation. As regards one's ‘good friends’, however, who are always too indolent 
and think that because they are one's friends they have a right to indolence: one 
does well to allow them from the first some room and latitude for misunderstanding 
— thus one can laugh at their expense; — or get rid of them altogether, these good 
friends — and still laugh!

Voltaire, and consequently a lot quieter. But, as I have already suggested, 
what happens more often is that the scientific head is placed on an ape's 
body, a more subtle and exceptional understanding is put in a base soul. 
This is not a rare phenomenon, particularly among physicians and physiologists of morals. And wherever even one person is speaking about man 
without any bittemess but instead quite innocuously, describing him as a 
stomach with dual needs and a head with one; wherever someone sees and 
seeks and wants to see only hunger, sex-drive and vanity, as if these were 
thesole and genuine motivating forces of human action; in short, wherever 
somebody is speaking “badly” of people — and not even mickedly — this is 
where the lover of knowledge should hsten with subtle and studious attention. He should keep his ears open wherever people are speaking without 
anger. Because the angry man, and anyone who is constantly tearing and 
shredding himself with his own teeth (or, in place of himself, the world, or 
God, or society), may very well stand higher than the laughing and selfsatisfied satyr, considered morally. But considered in any other way, he 
is the more ordinary, more indifferent, less instructive case. And nobody 
hes as much as the angry man. —
translations.Faber:
Making yourself understood is hard—especially if you live and 
think gangasrotogati,* amidst people who all think and live differently, namely kurmagati, or in the best case, ‘in the manner of 
frogs’, mandeikagati (am I doing all I can to make myself hard to 
understand, too?), and we should be sincerely grateful to anyone 
who cares enough to achieve some subtlety as an interpreter. But 
as for ‘good friends’, who are always too comfortable and think 
that as friends they are entitled to be so: it is wise to start by 
granting them elbow room and a playground for misunderstanding—then there is still an occasion for laughing—or else just

do away with them entirely, these good friends—and laugh about 
that, too!
